elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: These war-torn stretches offer little in the way of relief or comfort. We should pass through here as quickly as we can. [Few opportunities of use, and strange enemies are abroad in this place.]

elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: These war-torn stretches offer little in the way of relief or comfort. We should pass through here as quickly as we can. [Few opportunities of use, and strange enemies are abroad in this place.]

elements.label: Cradle of the Star
elements.description: A stray light in the sky - a distant spark of empyrean fire, struck from the ceiling of heaven by the Lionsmith's hammer. I can feel its light calling me north, even from here. I must follow after it.

elements.label: Cradle of the Star
elements.description: Fateful night in Montecassino. Streaks and ribbons of flinty light make the sky strange. The smoke of one great battle billows behind; the fire of another waits ahead. The Lionsmith's gift waits to be claimed - but I am not the only one trying to claim it. Hasten, hasten.

elements.label: Paestum
elements.description: The earliest Allied landings occurred here. American infantrymen rushed up the beachheads in the first day, but the Germans have been quick to set up a defence. Fighting has spread in and around the small town. Let us help these Americani find their footing in Italy.

elements.label: Paestum
elements.description: Like many of the oldest places in Rome, Paestum began with the Greeks. The three temples they built to their gods can still be seen from the village, the ancient stone scarred by rain, by wind, by time. Both the Allies and the Germans have agreed to exclude those temples from the zone of combat - is the Colonel being sentimental in his age? An amusing thought.

elements.label: Potenza
elements.description: War in high-perched Potenza, along the spine of the Appenine mountains. The fresh mountain air should do us some good as we go about our bloody work.

elements.label: Potenza
elements.description: Romans, Bourbons, and now Germans - Potenza has known its fair share of oppressors, thanks to its favourable position atop the mountains. But the Romans are gone, as are the Bourbons. I do not think the Germans see the pattern. A great pity.

elements.label: Salerno
elements.description: Bloody beach landings by the British and Americans near the port of Salerno. German machine gun nests carve up the coast. The Allies are here to help us, but who's going to help them? Let's see what we can do.

elements.label: Salerno
elements.description: Salerno is a city of patriots. The dream of Risorgimento took deep root here, and when the call of unification sounded, the people of Salerno donned the red and shed their noble blood for Italy's sake. Now, eighty years hence, we will repay their dedication with our own, and break the German hold over this city of the free.

elements.label: Benevento
elements.description: St. Bartholomew's city has been thoroughly tenderised by a generous Allied bombing run, but enough Germans remain that the city will still be an effort to liberate. Go among the stones, the fires, and strike down the occupiers.

elements.label: Benevento
elements.description: In the shadow of Trajan's Arch, I am forced to reflect: I am an Italian, not a Roman; I am a warrior, not a murderer; I have chosen deliberately where to place my loyalties, and from where to withdraw them. And here, of course, is where I scattered the ashes of one whom I loved.

elements.label: Napoli
elements.description: The Napolitani have heard the call to arms! Radio reports confirm that the people have thrown the city into glorious chaos, rising up against the German occupiers ahead of any Allied arrival. Haste is what we need now. I will not let such a flame die out.

elements.label: Napoli
elements.description: Napoli is known to the invisible world as 'The City of Blood' and also as 'The City of the Little Door'. St Januarius, after all, was made a martyr here, or made a Name. No-one in the Church can make up their mind about which it was, but that's Januarius for you. I'll leave that headache to the theologians. My business is with the Germans, and today, it is their blood that is an immediate interest of mine.

elements.label: Campobasso
elements.description: Canadian troops carved out a small foothold here, purchased painstakingly with blood and steel. Thanks to them, more allies trickle into Campobasso day by day - but a hefty garrison of Germans retains control of the city centre and the northern outskirts. Dislodging them will be a strenous, but noble work.

elements.label: Campobasso
elements.description: Smoke in the piazza. Here is the bell that once sat in a church tower; here is the collapsed arch of the city hall; here is the beckoning figure of a stone angel, headless in the street.

elements.label: Termoli
elements.description: A storm of steel amasses - the British send forth their tanks against the Germans, whose thundering panzers froth and smoke like the hounds of hell. The combat will be a mess of gore and fire. Not being there this instant makes my fists ache with longing.

elements.label: Termoli
elements.description: Termoli al mare - a quiet place of pale promontories and old walls. I would come here once every summer for the silence and the sun. Now, my favorite caf√© has a tank smashed through its front. That makes me angry.

elements.label: Minturno
elements.description: Minturno is one of several stronghold-towns on the Gustav Line. Allied air support thrums in the skies above and behind. How much will the bombs bleed the town's defenders? How many lives will we have to end on the ground, by hand? The bombs are falling, now. If we go to Minturno, we will find out.

elements.label: Minturno
elements.description: I remember fighting here, a very long time ago, when dead Saracens drifted by in the waters of the Gargliano. That day, the Pope himself led the charge that broke their lines. I have never had much reason to favour the Church, but a leader brave enough to die with his soldiers? That impressed me.

elements.label: Gaeta
elements.description: The German occupiers, realizing the strategic importance of the port city, have declared an exclusion zone over Gaeta. Hundreds of gaetani, expelled from their homes, beg intervention and liberation. Something as paltry as an exclusory declaration won't stop me from obliging them.

elements.label: Gaeta
elements.description: Here the last king of the Two Sicilies was relieved of his crown by Garibaldi's Thousand; here Il Duce himself passed in shame as the Carabinieri shipped him to Ponza for imprisonment. One may ask, what upheaval is to come next to Gaeta? Well, I have an answer. A blunt one.

elements.label: Montecassino
elements.description: The broad face of the Gustav Line glowers at the soldiers and partisans come to liberate the valley. On the rocky hills, the Germans have almost every advantage: elevation, visibility, protection. To advance within the range of their artillery is death. But Montecassino is the gateway to Rome - the death of its defenders is thus non-negotiable.

elements.label: Montecassino
elements.description: On the highmost hill of Cassino once stood Apollo's temple. Then came Benedetto da Norsia, who raised the Invictine cross over the pagan icons and established the famous abbey. But now on the highmost hill there is only a blasted ruin, where German soldiers sleep in the aftermath of Allied bombing. It is said that Eternity is cruel, but History never brought forth into the world a thing it did not intend to destroy. C'est la guerre.

elements.label: Pontecorvo
elements.description: That wretched Austrian initially named the defensive line passing through this town after himself. Fearing for his image should it be breached, it was renamed after one of his sorry generals only a few short weeks ago. Soon he'll have to withdraw more than just his name from Italy.

elements.label: Pontecorvo
elements.description: This town is significant to a power of the Wood, and the bridge at its heart is where that power is known to roost. Il ponte del corvo - I have heard of people crossing that bridge alone and finding their pockets empty on the other side. I have heard of people crossing that bridge and not reaching the other side at all. Hopefully that hungry power is too busy picking at the dead to snatch up any of the living.

elements.label: Ortucchio
elements.description: In the region of Abruzzo, southeast of il Lago Fucino, Ortucchio lies as quiet as a corpse. No battle rages here. Yet, a small force of Germans is en route to the small town. Nothing good could have drawn them here, because there is nothing good in Ortucchio. Not after the Incident.

elements.label: Ortucchio
elements.description: Ill-omened Ortucchio, where the mists are blinding and the nights whisper threats. Not even a bird sings. Few lived here even before the war, and those who remain stay only because 'the palazzo keeps us here.' I suspect something has gotten into the water. I suspect the castle on the hill is not empty.

elements.label: Ortona
elements.description: Wave after wave of Allied soldiers crashes and breaks upon a determined German defence here - 'Little Stalingrad', they're calling it on the radio. Lets see for ourselves how determined these fascisti really are.

elements.label: Ortona
elements.description: Tight streets, packed with rubble. Hidden German machine gun emplacements rip into armoured convoys; booby traps lie waiting to maul unsuspecting soldiers. House-to-house the enemy fights us, and savagely. But at least we're by the sea.

elements.label: Valmontone
elements.description: An important stop, the Allies say, on the warpath to Rome - so important, in fact, that they rained bombs upon it for nearly a week. That still wasn't enough to uproot the fascist defenders. We will move in to clean up.

elements.label: Valmontone
elements.description: Prince Pamphili bought the whole town in the 17th century, hoping to elevate it to his tastes. To his credit, he did make the town very beautiful - but war, ugly and indelicate, makes quick work of beauty. Had I not been there to see it all being built, it would be hard to believe there had once been a town here at all.

elements.label: Velletri
elements.description: Anothing bracing point on the Caesar Line, crumbling now as our comrades converge on Rome. German desperation is palpable in the air. They might do something drastic to delay liberation's furious approach.

elements.label: Velletri
elements.description: Mussolini reclaimed the Pontine Marshes to the south with bold industrial directives, but the Germans have undone all that, now. Dynamited dikes flood cropfields with brackish water; malaria wastes rebels and occupiers both to the bone; the mud is rancid with blood. Pestilence and famine claim no allegiances - that is both a blessing and curse here, in ailing Velletri.

elements.label: Anzio
elements.description: Between the marshes and the mountains, the Allies struggle to drag themselves north, to Anzio, then to Rome. The Wehrmacht's Winter Line has made it a painful process. There will be more pain before it's finally over, but with our help, we can ensure most of it will be the enemy's.

elements.label: Anzio
elements.description: The German shelling has continued for weeks, now. The caves at nearby Pozzoli have been some refuge, but the Germans sometimes send their men to smoke us out and kill us in the dark. And every so often, it rains.

elements.label: Rome
elements.description: All roads, it is said, lead to Rome. Well, here is the road.

elements.label: Rome
elements.description: Rome has been many things, is many things: the seat of emperors; the city of the She-Wolf; the knot where all roads of the world and beyond once met. To the powers of struggle, Rome has always been the Colonel's city. To me, Rome is where I learned to hate chains. But today, as the bombers wheel overhead and the fires burn - as battle rises to its bloodiest zenith, Rome is where I will make a Name for myself.

elements.label: Rome
elements.description: The Germans and their allies have withdrawn from Rome, declaring it an open city - they have surrendered. Cheering crowds will meet us as we march in; adoring hands will throw flowers of victory. I tell myself this is good; my country is almost free. This is good, isn't it?
